title: Llanymynech Hill and Rocks Walk Route

images.caption: Hoffmann Lime kiln. Top of Hoffmann lime kiln at Llanymynech heitage area. Firing of the kiln was done from the top as can be seen from the figure in the distance.

images.title: Chris Heaton / Old Quarry on Llanymynech Hill
images.caption: Old Quarry on Llanymynech Hill. Part of the old quarry workings on the hill, showing heavily excavated scarring on the sheer rock face, although nature is beginning to take a foothold. The Offa's Dyke National Trail passes close to this spot.

images.title: Tim Heaton / Offa's Dyke Path round Llanymynech Hill
images.caption: Offa's Dyke Path round the hill. After climbing the south flank of the Hill, the Path takes a level course round the base of the summit's limestone crags.

images.title: Tim Heaton / View towards Llanymynech Hill
images.caption: View towards Llanymynech Hill. The white house is just in Wales; the Wales/England border running exactly along the right-hand edge of the picture.

images.title: Tim Heaton / Llanymynech Golf Course
images.caption: Llanymynech Golf Course. A course with some holes in Wales and some in England. The Offa's Dyke Path skirts the fairway along the line of trees.

description: This walk climbs to Llanymynech Hill and Asterley Rocks above the village of Llanymynech in Powys, Wales. The village is a lovely place for a stroll with easy trails along the Montgomery Canal and a more challenging climb to the lovely viewpoint to the north of the settlement. It sits in a significant position right on the England/Wales border. The walk starts in the village where you can pick up the Offa's Dyke Path and follow the waymarked footpath north to the the Heritage area which includes the Montgomery Canal visitor centre, the Hoffmann Lime Kiln and the old quarry. Soon after you will come to Asterley Rocks and Llanymynech Hill which stands at a height of 225 metres and includes an Iron Age hillfort and a Trig Point. There's splendid views here over the surrounding hills and countryside. You can then follow paths around the hill and the adjacent golf course before returning to the village.
